Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled



Veolia Environmental Services (Veolia) operates a fully permitted hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility (TSDF) and fuels blending facility in Henderson, Colorado.  The facility receives waste materials, primarily organic solvent wastes, from various manufacturers.  Once on-site, the waste materials are separated into various waste and product categories depending on how the material will be processed.  Certain types of wastes are treated and processed in order to recover products that may be reused/recycled by industrial customers.  Other wastes are prepared for shipment to other Veolia or non-Veolia facilities for additional treatment or disposal. 



There are (will be) two particular processes at the facility that have the capacity to store a regulated chemical (piperidine) in a quantity sufficient to require the preparation and implementation of this Risk Management Plan (RMP). The two processes will be performed on an event basis for one year.  This RMP plan will be terminated at the end of the one year.  Process 1 involves the storage/handling & recovery/recycling of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP).  Starting in August 2014, crude NMP containing 1.25% piperidine will be delivered to Veolia and stored in fourteen (14) temporary 21,000 gallon frac tanks.  The NMP in the frac tanks is run through an existing distillation unit to recover the NMP which is then sent back to the PSM regulated stationary tanks located among the facility's existing tank farms.  The recovered NMP is then distributed as a product to customers.  Waste piperidine generated from the recovery process in the form of condensate and still bottoms will be shipped off for treatment and disposal at third party facilities.  Assuming all 14 frac tanks are in operation and all NMP contains 1.25% piperidine, it is estimated that approximately 31,000 pounds of piperidine may be present on-site in the NMP recycling process. 



Pr

ocess 2 also involves the storage/handling & recycling/recovery of NMP containing piperidine.  Waste NMP will be stored in stationary tanks located among the facility's existing tank farms.  A maximum of 100,000 gallons of waste NMP is expected to be stored at the facility containing 3.75% piperidine, though a maximum of 60,000 gallons is expected to be stored in any given tank farm at the facility (the remainder spread among the other tank farms).  This corresponds to approximately 19,500 pounds of piperidine on-site in the waste NMP process.



There are no other processes at the facility currently storing, handling, using, or processing chemicals in quantities sufficient to require their inclusion in this RMP.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at Facility



Veolia is committed to protect their employees, the public and the environment.  The Veolia Health and Safety Program Plan is implemented throughout all Veolia facilities, service centers, remote job sites and field offices.  The Veolia Program Plan has been developed to comply with all applicable Safety and Environmental Health Regulations. Guidance provided by the Veolia Health and Safety Program Plan shall be implemented wherever possible in all countries in which Veolia conducts business.



On the Corporate Level, executive responsibility to safely manage all hazardous waste operations rests with the Vice President of Law and Compliance. The Director of Health and Safety has the authority to develop and require implementation of corporate-wide safety and health programs to promote a safe, healthful work environment and to promote regulatory compliance.  At the regional level, the Regional Vice President has executive responsibility to safely manage all operations in the region for which they have responsibility. The Regional Vice President shall provide the resources and leadership necessary to ensure the promotion of a safe and healthful work environment for all employees.

The Regional Health and Safety manager shall ensure that at a minimum, all elements of the Veolia Health and Safety Program Plan are being implemented in compliance with all federal, state and local regulations.  Branch Managers are responsible for providing the necessary resources for meeting the requirements of the Veolia Health and Safety Plan, at the branch level and are responsible for the safety of their employees and the operations under their control.  Operation Managers and Supervisors are responsible for the safety of their employees and operations under their control. They are to ensure that their employees are following the requirements set out in this program.  Employees are responsible for working safely and following the requirements of this program. Employees are also responsible for reporting any unsafe acts or conditions to their supervisors or managers.



Veolia is committed to protecting and enhancing the environment and to operating facilities in full compliance with all applicable laws. Component number seven of Veolia's corporate Environmental Policy outlines Veolia's commitment towards risk reduction: 

 

Veolia will operate in a manner designed to minimize environmental, health and safety hazards. Veolia will minimize  risk and protect employees and others in the vicinity of operations by employing safe technologies and operating procedures and by being prepared for emergencies.  Veolia will adopt safe working practices, train employees on these practices and insist that these safe work practices be followed.  Veolia will make available to employees and to the public information related to any operations that could cause environmental harm or pose potential health or safety hazards.  Veolia will mandate that employees report any condition that creates a danger to the environment or poses health or safety hazards and will provide confidential means for them to do so.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Pr

evention Steps



The Henderson facility is regulated by the Colorado Department of Public Health & Environment (CDPHE) and the local sanitary sewer district. The US EPA Region 8 is also involved in TSCA compliance and enforcement oversight (for the limited on-site TSCA storage). 



CDPHE Permits include a Part B permit (expires September 2019) that covers storage and processing operations; and a Synthetic Minor Air Construction Permit last amended March 2008 (no expiration date). 



Veolia's Henderson Facility is subject Process Safety Management (29 CFR 1910.119).  The Facility has established and implemented an Emergency Action Plan.  Veolia's Emergency Action Plan is incorporated within IX-02 PSM-12 Emergency Planning and Response.  Veolia Henderson has developed the following policies, plans and procedures to comply with the requirements 6.0 of this policy, 1910.38 and 1910.120(p):

-    Contingency Plan

-    Evacuation Procedures including Health and Safety Plan (HASP)

-    Storage and Segregation

-    Site Inspections

-    Fire Prevention and Control

-    Self-Assessment

-    Training

-    Fire Prevention and Control



The Emergency Action Plan has been developed in a manner to minimize hazards to human health, the environment and property from fires, explosions, or any unplanned release of hazardous waste or hazardous substance at the Facility.   Policies and procedures are in place to respond to a release.  The Facility also has procedures in place to investigate the root cause of an incident and implement corrective actions.  



In addition to the Emergency Action Plan, the Henderson Facility administers programs in regard to mechanical integrity including preventive maintenance, management of change, process hazard analysis and all other elements covered within the PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119).  All equipment at the facility is designed by qualified engineers and contractors.  Inspections of equipment, materials, and processes are performed to identify and correct d

eficiencies.

  

As a result of the VES Process Safety Management (PSM) assessment, staff operation areas have been relocated to secure locations away from waste storage areas (including the staff shower room and solvent distillation control room), lower explosive limit (LEL) monitoring equipment has been installed in waste storage areas (e.g., at tank batteries), and foam fire suppression systems are installed at all storage/handling locations (e.g., foam cannons, overhead deluge systems). The fire-fighting equipment can be remotely controlled via Wi-Fi connections. 



High level alarms are present on the tanks (activate at 80% full), with sight gauges to prevent overfilling. All unloading of wastes and loading of blended materials are conducted over concrete. A high level alarm must be responded to with a manual pump shutdown for truck-to-tank transfers. Operator attention is also a major spill and leak prevention measure used at the facility. 



A facility-specific Compliance Management System (CMS) is used to track items such as annual requirements for testing waste tank wall thickness. Over 600 compliance elements are currently programed into the CMS (e.g., self-inspections, housekeeping). 



Veolia has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.



Five Year Accident History



There have been no accidents at the facility in the last five years involving the release of the chemicals covered by this RMP.



Emergency Response Program



Veolia's Henderson, CO facility maintains a Contingency Plan that describes the actions to be taken by employees in the event of a spill, fire, explosion or other emergency.  The Plan defines the responsibilities of the employees designated as Emergency Coordinators at the facility.  At all times there will be at

least one Emergency Coordinator (EC) on the premises or on call and available to reach the facility within 60 minutes.  In the event of an emergency, the EC directs the facility's response personnel and controls all activities until local emergency response responders arrive at the scene and the site is "turned over" to the responding authority.



The Contingency Plan outlines the procedures the EC follows in response to an emergency event including the following:

-    Activating the facility's internal communication system to alert all facility personnel and initiate facility    evacuation procedures (if required);

-    Assessing/identifying the character, exact source, amount, and extent of any contamination as well as possible hazards to human health or the environment.  

-    Noting any injuries requiring medical attention.

-    Notifying local emergency responders as appropriate as well as the applicable department in Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) in the event of a release or fire.  The Plan identifies the information to be included in these notifications.

-    Preventing the spread of fires, explosions and releases by, where applicable, stopping processes and operations, collecting and containing released waste, and removing or isolating containers.

-    Directing the facility's emergency response team (ERT) to initiate appropriate fire control procedures within the measures discussed or practiced during the facility's training program.

-    Advising the South Adams County Fire Department in response to fire/explosion events.

-    Directing clean-up operations related to chemical spills.



In addition to the responsibilities of the EC, the Contingency Plan also outlines procedures to be followed by Supervisors/Managers and all other employees.  This includes ensuring all containers are identifiable, supervisors/managers are familiar with the chemical inventory of their department, and protective clothing and proper safety equipment is provide

d and their use enforced when handling chemicals.  In addition, the Contingency Plan outlines the procedures for responding to chemical spills, natural disasters, and properly evacuating the facility.



Arrangements have been made to familiarize the police department, fire department, and local emergency response teams with the layout of the facility, the properties and hazards of the materials handled at the facility, the locations where facility personnel normally work, entrances to the facility, and possible evacuation routes.  Arrangements are also made to familiarize the local hospital with the types of injuries or illnesses that could result from fires, explosions, or releases at the facility.  Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs) for products commonly stored on-site are available to all employees and have been distributed to those entities with which arrangements have been made.



The EC receives comprehensive training in emergency response including emergency preparedness, knowledge of the site evacuation plan and procedures, knowledge of materials stored on-site and their locations, effective utilization of safety equipment, and firefighting.  The Emergency Response Team receives training in firefighting procedures.  As part of the facility's training program, employees are instructed in the nature and hazards of the chemicals with which they may come in contact.  All employees are trained on the facility evacuation procedures and evacuations drills are conducted quarterly.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



None planned at this time.
